questions.text: A 6-month-old infant visits the clinic with complaints of frequent respiratory infections. On examination, a cleft palate, difficulty in breathing, cyanosis, and a significant delay in growth are found. A defect involving which of the following structures is associated with this patient's underlying condition?
Which of the following is the most common congenital heart defect ?

A 7-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department after a fall from a tree house 1 hour ago. He complains of pain in his left arm. Physical examination reveals reduced sensations over the lateral part of the arm and weakness of abduction at 15-90 degrees. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: Injury to the lateral cord of the brachial plexus

options.label: C
options.text: Tearing of the Teres major muscle

options.label: D
options.text: Inferior dislocation of the head of the humerus

questions.correct_answer: D. Inferior dislocation of the head of the humerus

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient came to your consultant’s clinic complaining of pain over the penis and posterior surface of the scrotum for the past few months. He is a known case of IBS with constipation and is on and off medications for the same. You, being an intern, ask about any history of trauma/fall/surgery as you suspect pudendal nerve involvement which has the root value:-

A 43-year-old male complained of left flank pain, decreased urine output, and painful micturition. On diagnostic evaluation, a USG shows that the patient has a large stone that may require open surgery. Concerning essential surgical anatomy, a trainee surgical resident must know which of the following structure is unrelated to the ureter?
Which of the following is seen in a positive Trendelenburg sign in the right limb?

options.label: A
options.text: Difficulty in standing from a sitting position

options.label: B
options.text: The left side of the pelvis droops or sags when he attempts to stand with his weight, supported by the right lower limb.

options.label: C
options.text: The right side of the pelvis droops or sags when he attempts to stand with his weight, supported just by the left lower limb.

options.label: D
options.text: Weakened flexion of the right hip

questions.correct_answer: B. The left side of the pelvis droops or sags when he attempts to stand with his weight, supported by the right lower limb.

questions.text: Which ganglia is absent in the suspected disorder of a 28-year-old G2P1 mother's newborn who presents with no passage of meconium for 36 hours, bilious vomiting, the abdomen distended with hypoactive bowel sounds and a reducible umbilical hernia, tight anal sphincter, and explosive passage of air and feces on the removal of the examining finger?

A 68-year-old female presents with sudden changes in speech characterized by slow, limited utterances but with preserved understanding and task performance. Weakness in the right half of the face is noted. Suspecting a lesion or loss of blood supply, which Brodmann's area is implicated in this patient's condition?

A baby was born to a young woman whose pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios and was admitted to the intensive care unit because of repeated episodes of vomiting, which was containing bile. The stomach was moderately distended, and only small amounts of meconium passed through the anus. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male involved in a road accident undergoes a head CT, revealing an i ncidental tumor in the base of the skull , obscuring part of the jugular foramen. The Xth cranial nerve involvement is suspected. Which of the following muscles' actions cannot confirm this involvement through testing?

A 24-year-old cyclist participated in Tour de France competition. While making a sharp turn downslope, the cyclist suffered a fall and injured his right shoulder. In the hospital, an X-ray was taken, and it revealed that the patient had a fracture of the neck of the humerus. Which of the following is the most likely nerve involved?

A pediatric surgeon resects a possible malignant mass from a newborn baby's liver with cerebral palsy. The surgeon cuts the round ligament of the liver during the operation. A fibrous remnant from which of the following fetal vessels has been severed?

A 28-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with a complaint of dizziness and palpitations for one day. He gives a history of attending a bachelor party where he drank alcohol and played a few games. The physical examination shows no abnormality. There is a narrow QRS complex and indiscernible P waves on ECG. Which of the following is true in a patient with damaged cardiac muscle during the T-P interval in an ECG?

options.label: B
options.text: The entire ventricle is depolarized except for the damaged cardiac muscle

options.label: D
options.text: The entire ventricle is repolarized except for the damaged cardiac muscle

questions.correct_answer: D. The entire ventricle is repolarized except for the damaged cardiac muscle

questions.text: Intrathoracic pressure influences venous return and consequently cardiac output and arterial pressure. Inspiration drops intrathoracic pressure, causing a reflex increase in heart rate. Exhalation reverses the above steps. Which among the given options would produce the most negative intrathoracic pressure?
questions.explanation:
Conditions Negative Intrathoracic pressure
Under quiet breathing

Start of inspiration: -5 cm H2O

End of inspiration: -7 cm H2O
Muller's manoeuvre - 100cm H2O
The first cry of a neonate -60cmH2O
Yawning - 30 cm H2O

questions.text: In a physiology seminar, a group of medical students gives a presentation on renal physiology. They elaborate on the process of filtration and reabsorption. Filtration is the mass movement of water and solutes from plasma to the renal tubule that occurs in the renal corpuscle. About 20% of the plasma volume passing through the glomerulus at any given time is filtered. This means that the kidneys filter about 180 liters of fluid daily. Thus, the entire plasma volume (about 3 liters) is filtered 60 times daily. A substance is present in a concentration of 2 mg% in the afferent arteriole and 0 mg% in the efferent. A true statement about the substance is?

options.label: A
options.text: It is freely filtered at the glomerulus

options.label: D
options.text: Impermeable in the loop of Henle

questions.correct_answer: A. It is freely filtered at the glomerulus

questions.text: All of the following developmental events depend on the production of maternal or fetal glucocorticoids EXCEPT ?

options.label: B
options.text: Production of surfactant by type II alveolar cells

questions.text: A clinical study is conducted to determine the actions of an unknown test solution on red blood cell volume. One milliliter of heparinized human blood is pipetted into 100 milliliters of the test solution and mixed. Samples are taken and analyzed immediately before and at 1-second intervals after mixing. The results show that red blood cells placed into the test solution immediately swell and burst. Which of the following best describes the tonicity and osmolarity of the test solution?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypertonic; could be hyperosmotic, hypo-osmotic, or iso-osmotic

options.label: B
options.text: Hypertonic; must be hyperosmotic or hypo-osmotic

options.label: D
options.text: Hypotonic; could be hyperosmotic, hypo-osmotic, or iso-osmotic

questions.correct_answer: D. Hypotonic; could be hyperosmotic, hypo-osmotic, or iso-osmotic

questions.text: In a 40-year-old female, total blood flow to all the muscles is 800 ml/min, her arterial pO 2 is 90 mmHg, and her arterial pCO 2 is 50 mmHg. Now, her sympathetic system is activated, decreasing blood flow to 400 ml/min to all the muscles. What will happen to Venous pO 2 and Venous pCO 2 ?

A 29-year-old man presents to the physician’s office asking for dietary instructions. He eats a low-carbohydrate meal rich in proteins containing the amino acids that stimulate insulin secretion. Which response accounts for the absence of hypoglycemia?

A 67-year-old man comes to the cardiology clinic for a routine wellness visit. ECG shows no P wave but has a normal QRS complex and a normal T wave. With this given information, which is the most probable location of the pacemaker in this patient?
What is the main difference between the measurement of BP with a sphygmomanometer and intra-arterial pressure measurements ?

A surgeon presents an article on tetany to second-year medical students. He explains that sudden onset of carpopedal spasms can occur in perioperative patients. When a person hyperventilates, it can result in tetany. Which one of the following is the basis for carpopedal spasm in hyperventilation?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased sequestration of Ca 2+ in SER

options.label: B
options.text: Increased plasma protein binding of Ca 2+

options.label: D
options.text: Increased excretion of calcium in urine

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased sequestration of Ca 2+ in SER

questions.text: A loss of which of the following causes the hyperkinetic symptoms of Huntington's disease?
questions.correct_answer: D. Intrastriatal GABA-ergic and cholinergic system

questions.text: A group of neurologists is investigating action potentials and refractory nerve periods. What is the greatest nerve stimulation frequency if the nerve's refractory period is 1/2500th of a second ?
Which of the following TCA cycle enzymes is most likely to be affected by riboflavin deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Coenzyme Vitamin TCA cycle enzyme
Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) B1 (Thiamine)

α ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (also requires other 4 cofactors similar to Pyruvate dehydrogenase)
Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) B3 (Niacin)

Isocitrate dehydrogenase,

α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

Malate dehydrogenase
Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) B2 (Riboflavin)

Succinate dehydrogenase

questions.text: A 2-week-old child being breastfed is brought to the hospital by his mother because the infant appears restless . The mother also states that the infant has looked yellow since birth. On examination, the physician observed that the infant had icterus, hepatomegaly and bilateral cataracts . The blood examination shows normal blood glucose levels. What is the most probable reason for the child's symptoms ?

A patient presented to casualty with nausea and vomiting. Intravenous glucose was given & the patient recover ed. After a few months, the patient presented with the same complaints, along with increased blood glutamine and elevated uracil levels . What is the most likely diagnosis ?

A 28-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with elevated cholesterol levels of 325 mg/dL on a routine checkup. His father consistently had high levels of cholesterol throughout his life and eventually died of a heart attack at the age of 42. He was prescribed lovastatin , and his cholesterol levels dropped to 170 mg/dL . The most likely reason for the elevated cholesterol in this patient is due to a mutation in which one of the following proteins?
questions.explanation:
Deficiency/ Defect Disease
MTP deficiency Abetalipoproteinemia
LCAT deficiency Fish-eye disease (partial deficiency), Norum disease (complete deficiency)
Lipoprotein lipase deficiency Familial hyperchylomicronemia

questions.text: Several techniques such as PCR and in situ hybridization require DNA strands to be separated for analysis. Heating is one of the most common methods to denature a dsDNA into a single-stranded form. What percentage of dsDNA is denatured at a widely used temperature in molecular biology called Tm or melting temperature?

A 2-year-old male infant is presented to a pediatrician with dilated cardiomyopathy, hypothyroidism, inability to gain weight, dry skin, and failure to thrive. The patient is diagnosed with mineral deficiency, an essential component of the enzyme glutathione peroxidase . Based on the given information, which one of the following mineral supplements can help improve this child's condition?
Which amino acid substitution would enhance the protein's UV absorption at 280 nm in the lab?

In the graph below, Curve A is obtained for liver glucokinase, while Curve B is for muscle glucokinase under similar conditions. Which is the correct statement regarding the relationship between these enzymes ?

options.label: A
options.text: A is the same enzyme as B but in the presence of a competitive inhibitor

options.label: B
options.text: B has a greater affinity for glucose than A.

options.label: C
options.text: At maximal substrate concentrations, both enzymes display first-order kinetics.

options.label: D
options.text: B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (K m ) than A.

questions.correct_answer: D. B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (K m ) than A.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy was hospitalized after experiencing a seizure, lethargy and dehydration. The infant had reduced food intake due to a stomach infection, and the blood glucose level upon admission was 28 mg/dl. Urine analysis revealed the absence of ketone bodies but the presence of various dicarboxylic acids . What could be the underlying cause of fasting hypoglycemia in this case ?

options.label: A
options.text: Defect in converting acetyl CoA to glucose

options.label: B
options.text: High production of ATP and NADH

options.label: C
options.text: Increased conversion of acetyl CoA to acetoacetate

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy suffering from congenital deficiency of muscle phosphorylase is getting examined by an ischemic forearm exercise test by squeezing a rubber ball. This patient would exhibit which one of the following as compared to a normal person performing the same test?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

options.label: C
options.text: Increased lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

options.label: D
options.text: Relatively decreased blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

questions.correct_answer: D. Relatively decreased blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the Medicine outpatient department with complaints of easy bruising for three years. He has no risk factors and is not on any medication that could cause bruising. He reports no family history of any disease related to his condition. Further evaluation reveals a genetically transmitted disease. He is married to an albino girl. What are the possibilities that they will have an affected child and that their children will be carriers?
questions.correct_answer: A. None affected, and all carriers

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman had jaundice and was easily fatigable for the past few months. She also reports a racing heart and shortness of breath on exertion. Splenomegaly is discovered during the examination. Her history is significant for gallstones. According to the patient, her mother had a similar history of jaundice, and her father died of an ischemic stroke. Spherocytes can be seen in the patient's peripheral blood smear. Which of the following is the most important investigation to make a diagnosis?

A 45-year-old chronic smoker with retrosternal chest pain, cough, and choking. ECG showed sinus rhythm. The cardiologist rules out any cardiac involvement. Upper GI endoscopy revealed a punched-out ulcer, and a biopsy taken from the edge of the ulcer showed multinucleated squamous epithelium cells and eosinophilic Cowdry 'A' inclusions. Which of the following virus is involved in the disease's pathogenesis?

A 54-year-old man presents with a solitary breast mass, and a biopsy reveals malignant cells. Immunohistochemical staining shows that the tumour cells are positive for estrogen receptor (ER) and negative for Her2/neu. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old woman presents with complaints of increasing skin pigmentation for the past few months. The axilla, neck, flexures, and anogenital region all have hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation on physical examination . According to endocrinologic tests, adrenal corticosteroids and glucocorticoid levels in the blood are normal . If this patient's skin colouration represents a paraneoplastic syndrome, the main tumour would most likely be detected in which of the following anatomic areas?

A 46-year-old man is admitted to the medicine ward with complaints of pain in the lower limbs upon walking and blackening of the tips of his fingers. He has an 80-pack-year history of smoking. Laboratory investigations show haemoglobin of 15 g/dL, WBC of 8,300/μL, cholesterol of 223 mg/dL, and fasting blood sugar of 97 mg/dL. Tests for antinuclear antibodies are negative. Biopsy of the affected area (shown in the image) shows intraluminal thrombi in medium-sized arteries and inflammation extending from arteries to neighbouring veins and nerves. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of heavy bleeding from the vagina. She is concerned because she had her menopause three years ago. The ultrasonographic evaluation shows a large pelvic tumour with multiple locules. Surgery is planned, and the tumour is resected. The histopathological evaluation of the tumour reveals Call-Exner bodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Call-Exner bodies Granulosa cell tumour
Schiller Duval bodies Yolk-sac tumours
Reinke crystals Leydig cell tumour
Tennis-Racket cells Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents with involuntary facial grimaces and movements of the fingers. His mother also had the same symptoms starting at approximately the same age. Her disorder also had progressed from dancing movements, writhing of the arms and legs, and finally, coma and death. His maternal grandfather also had a similar disorder but was older than his mother. Which of the following is the most defining characteristic of this disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Degeneration of upper and lower motor neurons

options.label: B
options.text: Dopamine depletion and depigmentation of the substantia nigra

options.label: C
options.text: Increased number of trinucleotide repeats in a gene on chromosome 4

options.label: D
options.text: Neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques in the cerebral cortex

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased number of trinucleotide repeats in a gene on chromosome 4
questions.explanation:
Huntington’s disease
  • An autosomal dominant disease characterised by fatal, progressive degeneration and atrophy of the Striatum (Caudate nucleus and Putamen).
  • Characterised by an increased number of trinucleotide repeats (CAG) in the huntingtin gene on the short arm of chromosome 4.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting , and mild fever for one day. He further explains that the pain was initially in the periumbilical region but has moved to the lower right quadrant of the abdomen. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. On abdominal examination, there is maximum tenderness at McBurney's point . Laboratory tests reveal a WBC count of 14,000 / mm3, with 74% segmented and 12% neutrophils. Which of the following statements describes the expected results at the site of inflammation in the patient’s current pathology?

options.label: A
options.text: Fistula (abnormal duct or passage) connecting to the abdominal wall

options.label: B
options.text: Granulomatous inflammation with prominent aggregates of epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells

options.label: C
options.text: Massive infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells

options.label: D
options.text: Prominent areas of oedema, congestion, and a purulent reaction with localised areas of abscess formation

questions.correct_answer: D. Prominent areas of oedema, congestion, and a purulent reaction with localised areas of abscess formation

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the physician with complaints of severe anaemia for two months. She has been a known case of myasthenia gravis for eight years, for which he has been taking medication. Investigation results show a haemoglobin concentration of 4.7 g/dl, hematocrit at 13.7%, and reticulocyte counts at 0.1%. Both direct and indirect Coombs’s tests were positive. However, there was no evidence of Haemolysis. Screening tests for other possible causes of anaemia were negative. The bone marrow examination results revealed severe erythroid hypoplasia. Based on the clinical findings, which of the following condition is usually associated with this pathology?

A female patient presents to the clinic with fever and lymphadenopathy; a provisional diagnosis of leukaemia is made after a series of examinations. Her blood smear examination was sent to a pathologist, revealing leukaemia composed of small mature lymphocytes without blast forms. Which of the following is the patient's most likely age of this patient?

A twelve-year-old girl is brought to your clinic by her parents with complaints of high-grade fever. The fever has been going on for the past week. Examination findings reveal 38°C (101°F) temperature and lymphadenopathy. Initial laboratory findings are normal. A biopsy of the inflamed lymph node reveals benign follicular hyperplasia (shown in the image below). Which of the following best describes this pathologic finding?

A 50-year-old man has come to the clinic with complaints of fever, chills, and cough for the last 20 days . He also reports shortness of breath . He has also experienced mild weight loss. He is a farmer by profession and has had a history significant for uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension for the last 10 years. His father died from colon cancer at the age of 87. HRCT and biopsy are performed , which confirms the diagnosis of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Following statements are true regarding histological features of Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis, except:

A 28-year-old man presents with end-stage renal disease . On examination, right eye lens dislocation is found. His maternal uncle also died of the same illness. On electron microscopy of renal biopsy, a basket-weave appearance of glomerular basement membrane (GBM ) is seen. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy is brought to the paediatrician for a physical examination before beginning elementary school. On examination, the boy has only one palpable testis in the scrotum. Further examination shows a palpable mass in the inguinal region on the left side. What is this condition referred to as?

A 29-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of headache and palpitations. His blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. He reports similar symptoms in the past. After making a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is made. Which of the following familial syndromes is least likely to be associated with developing pheochromocytomas?

A 70-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his son 30 minutes after he lost consciousness. The son of the patient further explains that his father was playing with his 2-year-old grandson when he suddenly collapsed and became unresponsive for 2 minutes . The patient normally responded after regaining consciousness . He had an episode of mild abdominal discomfort and chest pain three months ago . He has been a known case of hypertension for the past ten years. The cardiac examination reveals a grade 3/6 late systolic murmur at the right sternal border that radiates to the carotid arteries . There is no erythema or swelling of the lower limb. The transthoracic echocardiogram confirmed the diagnosis of aortic valve stenosis . The patient was posted for aortic valve replacement , and the surgery was done. Immediately post-replacement of the aortic valve, the patient was kept on IV unfractionated heparin infusion . If its dosing can be evaluated and changed accordingly, when is the steady state concentration expected to be reached?

A 55-year-old with a history of overactive bladder, currently on oxybutynin, seeks a regular check-up after six years. He reports experiencing dry mouth since starting the drug and consumes 3L of water daily despite concerns about increased urination. The physician prescribes a more uroselective muscarinic antagonist . Which drug did the physician prescribe?
Which of the following statements about digoxin is the most accurate ?

options.label: A
options.text: Primarily acts by reducing sympathetic outflow, leading to decreased heart rate.

options.label: B
options.text: Contraindicated in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially in the elderly.

options.label: C
options.text: Narrow therapeutic window, requiring regular monitoring to avoid toxicity.

options.label: D
options.text: Administered concurrently with loop diuretics to enhance its efficacy.

questions.correct_answer: C. Narrow therapeutic window, requiring regular monitoring to avoid toxicity.
questions.explanation:
Definition Overdose or accumulation of digoxin, a cardiac glycoside
Clinical Presentation - Nausea, vomiting
  - Loss of appetite
  - Diarrhea
  - Visual disturbances (yellow-green halos)
  - Confusion, dizziness, headache
  - Cardiac symptoms: arrhythmias, bradycardia, palpitations
Severity Ranges from mild to life-threatening
Risk Factors - Impaired kidney function
  - Advanced age
  - Low potassium levels (hypokalemia)
  - Certain drug interactions (e.g., amiodarone)
Diagnosis - Serum digoxin levels
  - Electrocardiogram (ECG) for arrhythmias
  - Blood tests: electrolytes, renal function
Treatment - Discontinuation of digoxin
  - Administration of digoxin-specific antibody fragments (Digoxin Immune Fab)
  - Correcting electrolyte imbalances (e.g., potassium)
  - Symptomatic and supportive care

questions.text: An antimicrobial drug ‘X ’ can cause pseudotumor cerebri in infants even when given at normal doses. Identify the mechanism of action of this drug ‘X’?

options.label: A
options.text: Binding of a component of the 50S ribosomal subunits

options.label: C
options.text: Blockade of binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to bacterial ribosomes by binding to 30S ribosome

options.label: D
options.text: Selective inhibition of ribosomal peptidyl transferase

questions.correct_answer: C. Blockade of binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to bacterial ribosomes by binding to 30S ribosome

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents to her physician with complaints of persistent pain in her joints of both hands. She also complains of morning stiffness which lasts for approximately 2 hours . She was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis one year back and was commenced on ibuprofen, corticosteroids, and methotrexate. She is a non-smoker and drinks only occasionally. There is no history of any other comorbidity. She is vitally stable. Tender and swollen metacarpophalangeal joints and proximal interphalangeal joints are noted on examination. X-ray of the hands reveals erosions, joint space narrowing and soft tissue swelling. What is the next best step in treating this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Start monotherapy with anti-TNF alpha drugs

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with seizures and not responding to anticonvulsants since birth. She has abnormally tiny eyes and microcephaly . Her MRI brain reveals agenesis of the corpus callosum . Further examination reveals retinal colobomas and intellectual disability . Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

A 39-year-old male visits your clinic, reporting symptoms of a runny nose, cough, and throat pain , along with body aches. These symptoms emerged s hortly after he began antitubercular therapy, following a recent diagnosis of Tuberculosis. Which antitubercular drug is likely responsible for the patient's current condition?
Which of the following antiretroviral drugs is associated with acute pancreatitis?

A 33-year-old male with a family history of bipolar disorder was brought to a psychiatry clinic with complaints of elevated mood, non-stop talking, and paranoid behavior. His spouse mentions that he has not slept for five days and spent fifty thousand rupees on unnecessary shopping in a week. He is diagnosed with acute mania. Which of the following antipsychotics is the drug of choice for rapidly managing acute symptoms in this case?
Which of the following medications used in preventing and treating angina acts mainly through the opening of cardiac potassium channels ?

A 56-year-old male factory worker presents to the emergency department complaining of nausea, vomiting and fatigue. There were three episodes of vomiting, which was a non-projectile, watery containing food particle. There was no blood. He was recently diagnosed with bladder adenocarcinoma. He has been advised chemotherapy. Episodes of vomiting occur 48 hours after the first chemotherapy (cisplatin) session. Which drug is given to alleviate the patient's symptoms?

A 58-year-old male undergoing inguinal hernia repair is administered general anesthesia by an intern, who intends to use d-tubocurarine to relax skeletal muscles. However, the senior anaesthetist intervenes, citing d-tubocurarine's propensity to induce severe hypotension. What mechanism underlies d-tubocurarine's hypotensive effect?

A patient presented with complaints of stuff nose, sore throat, cough and hoarseness in voice in the morning session of the OPD. The doctor decided to send his sample for culture examination to the laboratory. The microbiologist cultured his sample on blood agar as shown in the image below. Identify the organism showing this Bacitracin sensitivity test.
questions.explanation:
Streptococcus pyogenes Streptococcus agalactiae
CAMP CAMP test (-) ve (+) ve
Hippurate hydrolysis test (-) ve (+) ve
Bacitracin SENSITIVE RESISTANT

questions.text: A 22-year male presents to the emergency department with a fever and 2 days of bloody diarrhoea, and severe abdominal cramps. On examination, the boy looked very dehydrated with a blood pressure of 113/73 mmHg. On labs, the patient has an elevation of WBCs and ESR. The stool culture showed Gram-negative bacilli, non-motile, with no H2S production. Which of the following organism is the most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Presentation

 

 Identification features

 
Vibrio cholerae

 

 (Watery diarrhoea)

 

 Darting motility
  • Coma-shaped gram-negative bacilli in culture smear
  • Catalase and oxidase positive
  • TCBS agar: sucrose fermenting yellow-coloured colonies
  • ICUT tests: I+C+U-TSI (alkaline slant/ acidic butt, gas, H2S)
  • · Agglutinates with Vibrio cholerae 01 antisera and Ogawa antisera
Shigella

 

 Dysentery

 

 Gram –ve bacilli, non-motile
  • Catalase +ve oxidase –ve
  • MAC or DCA: NLF translucent
  • XLD: red colonies without black centre
  • ICUT test: I- C+ U- TSI (alkaline slant/ acidic butt, gas, H2S)
  • Agglutinates with Shigella polyvalent antisera and specific monovalent antisera

 

 

Group B Salmonella

 

 

Inflammatory diarrhoea

 Gram –ve bacilli, motile
  • Catalase positive, oxidase –ve
  • MAC: non-lactose fermenting translucent colonies
  • DCA: non-lactose fermenting colonies with a black centre
  • XLD: red colonies with a black centre
  • ICUT tests: I- C+ U- TSI (alkaline slant/ acidic butt, gas, H2S)
  • Agglutinates with Salmonella poly-O antisera and serotype (O4) specific.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of difficulty in breathing and persistent cough for several days. On examination, he has a black lesion on the upper bridge of the nose. His chest x-ray showed irregular solitary nodules. The physician recommended a tissue biopsy with H&E staining to ascertain the cause. The results of which showed Aseptate hyphae. Which of the following is the characteristic of the biopsy finding?

A 56-year-old male presents to the OPD with a complaint of abdominal pain and blood in the urine for the last three days. His examination reveals a blood pressure of 110/70mmHg with a regular pulse of 80/min. The rest of his general physical and systemic examinations are unremarkable. On microscopic examination of stools, sample eggs with terminal spine were seen. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism in this patient?

A 39-year-old homosexual HIV patient visits out door patient with OPD with complaints of visual disturbances. The patient is admitted as the patient has HIV. His CD4 count is measured, and on evaluation, the CD4 count measures 40 cells/mm 3 . All vitals are measured within normal limits. On Fundal examination , bilateral retinal exudates and perivascular haemorrhages are also noted. Physical examination and low CD4 indicate viral aetiology. A urine sample is collected for the PCR CMV test, and the results are suggestive of CMV retinitis. Which type of inclusion body is likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
CD4 count

Possible infection

<500

TB

<200

P. jiroveci

<100

Cerebral Toxoplasmosis

<50

CMV

M.A.C (mycobacterium avium complex)

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy living in rural India had a history of cowpox infection. His sister's rash on the skin turned into a fluid-filled blister with a dent in the center. On history taking, the patient says it was just nausea, vomiting, and fever in the beginning. Later, she started having ulcers in the mouth and a rash that turned into blisters. The doctor suspected it was a contagious viral infection. The strange thing, in this case, is that the boy who is her brother, despite coming in contact with his sister multiple times, was not infected. The boy's protection from this disease by the previous infection is due to the?

questions.text: A 65 - year - old woman with ASCVD complained of palpitations for the last 4 hours. On examination, her heart rate wa s 180 beats/min with B lood pressure 90/60 mm Hg. Which of the following is not recommended for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning objective:
  • ➤ The ECG displays a narrow complex tachycardia with a heart rate of about 180 beats per minute without P waves and a reduced regular RR interval. Furthermore, there is ST segment depression. Carotid sinus massage is the first line of treatment, but it is not advised in cases of carotid artery bruit. Known case of atherosclerotic carotid artery narrowing with ASCVD (atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease) (Carotid artery bruit). If a carotid sinus massage is administered to this patient, atherosclerotic plaque in the carotid artery may be physically damaged, result ing in an embolic stroke. Adenosine will return the sinus rhythm to normal. If it doesn't work, DC cardioversion is advised. Verapamil is used for rate control. Face packing and other techniques to enhance the vagal output control the rate in PSVT. ​​​​​​​

After initial management, an upper gastrointestinal tract endoscopy was done, which revealed bleeding from the lesser curvature of the stomach. An 80-year-old, asymptomatic man presents with a total leucocyte count of 100,000/uL, with 80% lymphocytes and 20% polymorphonuclear cells . What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia
  • Median age of presentation is 65 years, with 53% male presentation
  • Symptoms can vary from asymptomatic to fatigue(anaemia) and left upper quadrant pain or mass due to massive splenomegaly.
  • B-cell lymphocytosis greater than 5000/µL and co-expression of CD19, CD5 on lymphocytes are diagnostic of CLL.
  • Peripheral blood smear shows “smudge” or “basket” cells
  • Unexplained fever, significant weight loss, severe fatigue, bone and joint aches, bleeding and thrombotic events, and infections are symptoms of the accelerated or blast phase.
  • Warm autoimmune hemolytic anaemia (IgG) can also be seen
  • Bone marrow cellularity is increased, with an increased myeloid-to-erythroid ratio.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient presents to the neurology clinic with weakness in both lower extremities, progressively worsening tingling and numbness, and difficulty getting up from the chair. He has had a history of having laxity in both ankles since his 20s. He also has a tendency for his feet to turn inwards, trip, and subsequently sprain his ankles. Family history also reports having hammertoes in immediate family members involving his mother, sibling, and daughter. On examination, palpable nerves are seen. A typical onion bulb appearance is noted on a biopsy of the nerve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) Disease and Neuropathy
Muscle Appearance - Champagne bottle or stork-leg appearance due to peroneal muscle atrophy
  - Contrasts with pseudo-hypertrophy of calf muscles seen in Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy
Contractures - Foot contractures due to nerve involvement, leading to walking difficulties
Nerve Thickening - Thickened nerves with onion bulb appearance
Biopsy Findings - Onion bulb appearance also seen in Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy
  (a variant of Gullian-Barre Syndrome)

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with Parkinson's disease for the past 8 years presented to your clinic for regular follow-up. She has been on l evodopa with a good response for the past 8 years. She reported having some periods of improved mobility alternating with impaired motor function. She was diagnosed with the characteristic 'on-off' phenomenon. Which of the following is the new drug approved for the treatment of ‘off phenomenon’ in such patients?

A 48-year-old Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) positive patient presented with diarrhoea for 7 weeks to the outpatient department. Upon asking, he describes his bowel moment as watery , non-bloody, with a frequency of 5-6 episodes per day. He also informs that he feels fatigued and his clothes have become loose . His routine stool examination results had been negative. Which pathogen is most likely involved in this condition?

A 68-year-old male with a history of very severe COPD (FEV1~1.0L, <25% predicted) presents to the ER complaining of worsening dyspnea and an increase in the frequency and purulence of his sputum production over the past 2 days. His oxygen saturation is 78% on room air. Before he is placed on supplemental oxygen, a room air arterial blood gas is drawn and reveals pH=7.25, PCO 2= 68 mmHg, pO 2= 48 mmHg, HCO 3 - =31 mmHg. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to persistent shortness of breath and cough for the last 8 days. His respiratory status worsened while in the emergency department. He became severely short of breath and was unable to complete sentences. He smokes 2 packs of cigarettes a day. His blood pressure is 125/71 mm Hg, his heart rate is 122/min, his temperature is 37 ° C (98.6 ° F), his respiratory rate is 33/min, and his oxygen saturation is 77% on room air . His pCO2 is noted to be 55mmHg . He is transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure . Which is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.correct_answer: A. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbation
questions.explanation:
Type of COPD Description
Chronic Bronchitis - Characterized by chronic inflammation of the bronchial tubes (airways).
  - Excessive mucus production, leading to cough with sputum production.
  - Often associated with recurrent respiratory infections.
Emphysema - Involves damage to the alveoli (air sacs) in the lungs.
  - Loss of lung elasticity and reduced ability to exhale air effectively.
  - Leads to air trapping and increased work of breathing.
Mixed COPD - Some individuals may have features of both chronic bronchitis and emphysema.
  - Commonly referred to as "mixed" or "overlap" COPD.
Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency-Related COPD - Caused by a genetic deficiency of alpha-1 antitrypsin, an enzyme that protects the lungs from damage.
  - Can result in early-onset COPD, especially in non-smokers.

On auscultation, bilateral wheeze and right basal crackles are audible, with heart sounds best heard on the right side of the chest . CT chest revealed dextrocardia , and nodular opacities in bilateral lung fields suggest bronchiectasis . He also gives a history of not having children despite being married for the last 4 years. Which of the following could be the probable cause of infertility in patients with the above syndrome?

A 56-years-old patient presented to emergency with complaints of breathlessness, chest pain and drowsiness. He is a known case of lung carcinoma. Examination shows engorged and distended neck veins, low blood pressure, and soft S1 and S2. Which of the following is inappropriate regarding the condition of this patient?

A woman comes to a psychiatrist with a history of spending a lot of time in washing her hands. She is distressed about it but says that she is not able to stop washing. This has started to affect her social life as well. What is the best mode of treatment for her?

There are places famous for Cannabis use: Kerala, Meghalaya, Manipur, Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Mysuru, even Bihar. In Odisha, it is relatively more acceptable and easier to procure. In 1985, under pressure from the US (which had launched the war on drugs with much fanfare), Rajiv Gandhi clamped the draconian NDPS — the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act. This put traditional bhang and ganja on the same level as smack, brown sugar..etc. How long can a urine drug screen test stay positive for delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol in a heavy cannabis user?

When a 42-year-old guy with a sexual interest in children (pedophilia) is shown a videotape of youngsters, he receives an electric shock. Later, he becomes nervous in the presence of children and avoids them. This example exemplifies which of the following management techniques?
questions.explanation:
• Aversive conditioning is a management approach in which a maladaptive but pleasurable stimulus (for this man, sexual interest in minors) is matched with a painful stimulus (e.g., a shock) to create an association between the two.
  • Flooding is a type of behavioural therapy in which the highest level of stimulation is provided in the initial encounter.
  • Biofeedback-·Uses the operant conditioning principle·Useful for autonomic dysfunction-related illnesses such tension headaches.·For example, EMG can be used to modulate muscular tone in conditions like bruxism

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented to the psychiatric emergency department due to aggressive behavior, lack of sleep, singing and dancing on the streets, and claiming that he is a bigger star than all the Khans of Bollywood. The symptoms have been continuing for 3 weeks. At the time of examination, the patient appeared agitated and aggressive. Which of the following is the preferred treatment for immediate control of symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Mania Symptoms

  • Disconnected and fast thoughts
  • Grandiose beliefs
  • Inapproprate elation
  • Inapproprate irritability
  • Increased talking speed or volume
  • Poor judgement
  • Decreased need for sleep due to high energy

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 67-year-old female presents in the surgical outpatient department due to the progressively increasing size of her left breast for the last 2 months. She also complains of itching, heaviness, and an increased temperature in her left breast. Physical examination reveals widespread erythema, intense edema, and areolar erosion of the breast, with several enlarged axillary lymph nodes on the left side. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: N eoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and r adiotherapy

questions.correct_answer: A. N eoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and r adiotherapy

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
questions.explanation:
Contraindications to Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy
Absolute Relative
  • Unable to tolerate general anesthesia
  • Refractory coagulopathy
  • Gallbladder carcinoma
  • Diffuse peritonitis
  • Previous upper abdominal surgery with extensive adhesions
  • Severe cardiopulmonary disease
  • Morbid obesity
  • Pregnancy(controversial)
  • Cholangitis
  • Cirrhosis and/or portal hypertension
  • Cholecystenteric fistula

questions.text: A 55-year old male presents to the emergency department with acute right flank pain for the past 3 hours. He was prescribed painkillers and discharged . The next day, he presented again with severe pain and was referred to the urology department. A ureteric calculus associated with hydronephrosis is identified on the ultrasound abdomen. He is managed with a procedure shown in the following image. Which of the following is correct about the given procedure?

options.label: A
options.text: Gold standard lithotripter is Dornier unmodified HM-3

options.label: B
options.text: Steinstrasse is seen in cases of proximal ureteric obstruction

options.label: D
options.text: The maximum size of the stone removed is 1.5 cm

questions.correct_answer: A. Gold standard lithotripter is Dornier unmodified HM-3

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to a primary care physician complaining of chest discomfort for the last ten days . His primary care physician provides symptomatic treatment, which gives an initial improvement in symptoms. Afterwards, his chest discomfort started again, and he developed progressive dyspnea with exertion . A CT chest reveals a round, well-demarcated mass in the middle mediastinal compartment. Which of the following is rare enough to be included in the middle mediastinal masses found in the patient discussed above?

A 35-year-old male patient was brought to the hospital with an altered state of consciousness . He has a history of chronic liver disease. On examination, there are mild ascites and tremors . Laboratory values show: Total Bilirubin - 2.5 mg/dL Albumin - 3 g/dL INR=2.0 Which class of Child Turcotte Pugh score does the patient belong to?

questions.text: While attending an outpatient rotation of gastroenterology, a patient brought his investigation records, and the professors handed over a film to the resident. Identify the technique given in the image below.

A 45-year-old female with chronic NSAID abuse presents with massive hematemesis, hypotension, and tachycardia. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness . IV proton pump inhibitors are administered, and endoscopy reveals a bleeding peptic ulcer in the proximal duodenum . Which of the following vessels needs to be ligated in this patient to stop the bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Gastric ulcer

Duodenal ulcers

Abdominal pain

Pain increases with the meal.

Pain decreases with the meal.

H. Pylori infection

Chronic infection

Acute infection

Mechanism

Decreased mucosal protection against gastric ulcer

Decreased mucosal protection or increased gastric secretion

Causes

NSAIDS

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

Risk of carcinoma

Increase risk

Benign

Vessel

Branch of

Left gastric artery (largest artery to the stomach)

Celiac artery

Right gastric artery

Hepatic artery (or gastroduodenal artery)

Left gastroepiploic artery

Splenic artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is less likely to be descriptive of retroperitoneal fibrosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Most patients present with dull, non-colicky, lower back, flank, or abdominal pain.

options.label: B
options.text: Evidence of impaired renal function with an elevated blood urea nitrogen is common.

options.label: C
options.text: CT or MRI scan can be used to diagnose the disease.

options.label: D
options.text: The prognosis for nonmalignant retroperitoneal fibrosis is grim, with the progression of the disease until death occurring in most patients.

questions.correct_answer: D. The prognosis for nonmalignant retroperitoneal fibrosis is grim, with the progression of the disease until death occurring in most patients.

questions.text: A 5-month-old child is brought to the pediatrician's office for evaluation of a "lump" in his genital area . His birth history is unremarkable, and he has been feeding well. His parents report no other concerns except this lump. On physical exam, there is a tense and non-tender mass in the scrotum . The transillumination test is positive . What is the appropriate diagnosis for this condition?

A 30-year-old otherwise healthy male presented to the emergency department with complaints of pain and bluish discolouration of the left arm, hand, and fingers for three weeks. On examination, pulses were weak in the left upper limb. A chest X-ray showed a left cervical rib attached to the first rib . Dynamic angiography revealed a left subclavian artery occlusion . Which of the following options would be the best for the management o f this patient?

A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of multiple red spots on his trunk. He first noticed these several months ago, and some appear to have increased in size. One day ago, he scratched one of these spots, which bled for several minutes. A photograph of the lesions is shown in the image: Among the following clinical entities, which is this patient's most likely possible diagnosis?

A 52-year-old man presented to us with c/o epigastric pain and weight loss. He also gave a history of dyspepsia and progressively increasing jaundice with clay-colored stools with no history of fever or pruritus. On physical examination, there was evidence for icterus without any palpable neck lymphadenopathy. Abdominal and chest CT scan confirmed the presence of a tumor measuring 50 mm in the head of the pancreas. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) also indicated that the tumor was in contact with both the SMA and the SMV, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy revealed adenocarcinoma. On the basis of these clinical findings, the patient was diagnosed with Unresectable Locally Advanced Pancreatic cancer. Which of the following drug can be prescribed to the patient to increase his survival rate?

A 27-year-old female is admitted to the hospital with a complaint of abdominal swelling associated with a history of fever for 2 weeks. She is anemic with a Hb of 10.0 g/dl; liver functions were within normal limit; ESR = 70 mm/hr (Normal = <20). Based on her CT findings, she was diagnosed with GI tuberculosis. What is the most common indication for surgery in this patient?
