questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of purple spots on her body and frequent nose and gum bleeding episodes. On probing her history further, it was found that she hasa known case of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura and has been on steroid treatment for two months. On examination, the patient has a non-palpable purpura with gingival bleeding. Her platelet count is 8000/cu.mm. The patient is taken in for elective splenectomy . What is the most common post-splenectomy complication?
questions.explanation:
Complications of Splenectomy

Pulmonary complications

  • Left lower lobe atelectasis: A most common complication
  • Pleural effusion
  • Pneumonia

Thromboembolic complications:

  • DVT
  • Portal vein thrombosis

Hemorrhagic complications

  • Subphrenic hematoma

DVT prophylaxis is roughly recommended

  • In patients with hemolytic anemia or myeloproliferative disorders & splenomegaly, the thrombotic risk is heightened, particularly the risk of portal vein thrombosis

Changes in blood

  • Howell Jolly bodies and siderocytes
  • Leukocytosis and increased platelet count

Infectious complications

  • Subphrenic abscess
  • Wound infection

Pancreatic complications

  • Pancreatitis
  • Pseudocyst
  • Pancreatic fistula

questions.text: A 66-year-old male presented with symptoms of urinary hesitancy, poor urinary stream, post-void dribbling, and urine retention. The prostate was hard and nodular on digital rectal examination. Imaging showed extensive, calcified areas of the prostatic parenchym a. What is the correct statement about this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Benign prostate hyperplasia is a cause of prostate stones

options.label: B
options.text: Usually present at the peripheral zone of the prostate

options.label: C
options.text: No treatment is needed in this patient

options.label: D
options.text: No lamellar bodies are formed in prostatic calculi

questions.correct_answer: A. Benign prostate hyperplasia is a cause of prostate stones

questions.text: A forty-five-year-old woman presents to your clinic with the complaint of a pigmented lesion on her right thigh. Her medical history is insignificant. She says this lesion has gradually increased in size. She undergoes an incisional biopsy which reveals malignant melanoma with a thickness of 3 mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin, followed by radiotherapy

options.label: B
options.text: Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin and groin lymph node dissection

options.label: C
options.text: Wide local excision with a 2-cm margin and sentinel lymph node biopsy

options.label: D
options.text: Wide local excision with a 2-cm margin and groin lymph node dissection

questions.correct_answer: C. Wide local excision with a 2-cm margin and sentinel lymph node biopsy

questions.text: A male infant was born at 38+2 weeks gestation and birth weight of 3.42kg. Polyhydramnios was noted on antenatal scanning. On day one, the infant had repeated episodes of vomiting in between feeds and had not passed meconium from birth. Abdominal distension was evident and following NGT placement, there were bile-stained aspirates. The anus was patent. Abdominal radiography demonstrated dilated loops of bowel and a Gastrografin study showed no flow of contrast beyond the rectosigmoid junction. Which is a true statement regarding the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: A coffee bean sign is seen on radiography

options.label: B
options.text: Snowstorm sign on ultrasound is seen

options.label: C
options.text: Surgery is performed in complicated cases

options.label: D
options.text: The terminal ileum is dilated with a relatively dilated colon

questions.correct_answer: B. Snowstorm sign on ultrasound is seen

questions.text: Balu is a 15-year-old male adolescent referred to the weight clinic with a body mass index (BMI) of 50 . He is referred based on his history of severe obesity and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and for a discussion of weight loss surgery. The patient has tried a low-carbohydrate and low-fat diet, reduced his portion sizes, worked with a nutritionist, and increased his level of physical activity, but could not achieve or maintain a healthy body weight. After evaluating the patient, bariatric surgery, specifically a laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG ), is Balu’s best option to treat his severe obesity. Which of the following is a feature of bariatric surgery ?

options.label: A
options.text: Indication for bariatric surgery: patients with a BMI of 25 Kg/m 2 or more with comorbidities.

options.label: B
options.text: The most commonly performed bariatric procedure nowadays is Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

options.label: C
options.text: Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding is irreversible

options.label: D
options.text: The most common cause of death within 30 days of bariatric surgery is peritonitis due to an anastomotic leak

questions.correct_answer: B. The most commonly performed bariatric procedure nowadays is Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
questions.explanation:
Bariatric operation

Mechanism of action
  • Vertical banded gastroplasty
  • Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding (Safest and reversible)
  • Restrictive
  • Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB): Most commonly performed procedure nowadays
  • Largely Restrictive / Moderately malabsorptive
  • Biliopancreatic diversion (Maximum weight loss)
  • Duodenal switch
  • Largely Malabsorptive/Mildly Restrictive

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presented to the emergency room after a motorcycle accident. Vital signs were within normal limits, and abdominal pain and two incised wounds on the right side of the abdomen were found on physical examination. CT scan showed multiple lacerations on the right renal parenchyma with mild urinoma . With the result of the CT and the patient’s clinically stable status, a conservative approach was decided. Now on follow-up after 12 days, the urinoma has persisted, but the patient is stable, and there is no fever . Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of malaise and abdominal pain. Eight weeks ago , he underwent liver transplantation for primary sclerosing cholangitis. At the time of discharge, his total serum bilirubin concentration was 1.0 mg/dL. His current medications include daily tacrolimus, prednisone, valganciclovir, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), his pulse is 95/min, and his blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg. Examination show s scleral icterus. H is leukocyte count is 2500/mm3, serum bilirubin concentration is 2.6 mg/dL, and serum tacrolimus concentration is within the therapeutic range. Biopsy of grafted donor tissue reveals graft rejection. Which statements regarding the rejection of solid organ transplants are true?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperacute rejection begins in the operating room with reperfusion of the transplanted organ

options.label: B
options.text: Liver transplants are especially susceptible to hyperacute rejection.

options.label: C
options.text: Most immunosuppressive medications are used to prevent chronic rejection.

options.label: D
options.text: The major cause of graft failure is acute rejection.

questions.correct_answer: A. Hyperacute rejection begins in the operating room with reperfusion of the transplanted organ
questions.explanation:
Transplant Rejection
Type

 

 Onset

 

 Mechanism & Vessel Histology

 

 Type of Hypersensitivity

 
Hyperacute

 

 Immediate

 

Minutes to days

 Preformed antibodies directed against the donor tissue. Caused by accidental ABO blood type incompatibility, which is very rare. Presents while still in surgery with thrombosis and occlusion of graft vessels

 

 II

 
Acute

 

 Weeks to months

 

 T-cell mediated immune response directed against the foreign MHC. Inflammation and leukocyte infiltration of graft vessels results.

 

 IV

 
Chronic

 

 Months to years

 

 T-cell mediated process resulting from the foreign MHC "looking like" a self MHC carrying an antigen. Results in intimal thickening and fibrosis of graft vessels, as well as graft atrophy

 

 III & IV

 
Graft vs Host

 

 Varies

 

 Donor T-cells in the graft proliferate and attack the recipient's tissue. Most commonly seen in bone marrow transplants. Presents with diarrhoea, rash and jaundice

 

 IV

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with spinal tuberculosis at the level of L 3 vertebrae with paraplegia and with 43 degrees kyphosis. Preoperative imaging demonstrated gross destruction of L3 vertebrae with spinal cord compression. The post-operative imaging has been given below. Identify which of the following statements are not true regarding the surgical intervention.

options.label: A
options.text: ALD and AD results are the same

options.label: B
options.text: ALD: position of the patient is left lateral

options.label: C
options.text: ALD: Laminectomy is always a part.

options.label: D
options.text: ALD: part of ribs is removed and spinal nerves exposed.

questions.correct_answer: C. ALD: Laminectomy is always a part.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a history of a fall one hour ago. He complains of right upper arm pain. No visible swelling is noted on examination. After administering pain medication, an X-ray is ordered. An X-ray of the upper limb is shown below. Keeping in view the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is not the treatment modality for the underlying disorder?

A 20-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident 20 minutes ago. He sustained an injury to the wrist and complained of wrist pain . On examination, he is vitally stable. Hands deformities are noted as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old boy presents to the clinic for the evaluation of his arm deformity for the past 2 months. Four months ago, he fell from the roof and got his humerus fractured. At that time, he was treated by a local doctor for his injury. On examination, his arm findings are given below.Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current deformity?

A 48-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his son with complaints of left-side chest pain radiating to the left arm for 1 hour. The patient looks restless and is sweating profusely. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. He has been diabetic for five years. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The ECG of the patient was done, which revealed ST elevation in the inferior leads. The patient had an inadequate response to all non-surgical therapies. The patient was posted for coronary artery bypass graft surgery under general anaesthesia. After the administration of premedication, preoxygenation should be done for denitrogenation and to overcome the apneic period during intubation. Ideally, this patient should be pre-oxygenated for:

A 27-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department in a confused state, complaining of headache , nausea, and shortness of breath. She explains that she was sleeping in a room with the heater on the whole night. There is no history of any comorbid conditions. On examination, BP=100/60mmHg, HR=112/min, SpO 2 =97% and RR=30 breaths/min. Which of the following poisoning can be suspected?

A 45-year-old male patient with a history of falls and trauma to the head is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state; a CT scan shows "EDH," and he undergoes a decompressive craniotomy. He was shifted to ICU for elective postoperative ventilation. The patient was sedated and paralyzed with infusions of propofol, midazolam, and Injection vecuronium. On 3rd day, his Blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse rate is 48/minute, and SpO 2 is 96% at room air. Blood investigations showed Hb-13g/dl, blood urea-80 mg/dl, serum creatinine is 3 mg/dl, PH-7.15 , PO 2 -200 mmHg, PCO 2 -20 mmHg, HCO 3 - -15 mmol/l, Na + 140 mEq/l, K + 5.8 mEq/l , blood cholesterol-350 mg/dl, triglycerides are 300 mg/dl. Ultrasonography Abdomen revealed hepatomegaly . Chest X-ray is normal. The most probable diagnosis will be?

A 45-year-old male who is a case of pleomorphic adenoma of parotid is being posted for superficial parotidectomy under general anaesthesia. The patient is induced with Inj. Thiopentone sodium and cisatracurium are used to facilitate endotracheal intubation and maintenance. Which of the following features of cisatracurium reduces the chances of hemodynamic instability in this patient?

A 2-month-old boy was brought to the physician's office with cyanotic spells since birth . On physical examination, there was central cyanosis, ejection systolic murmur at the left mid to upper sternal border , and radiological findings as given below . After examination, an ECG was done, which showed right axis deviation . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis ?

options.label: B
options.text: T etr a logy of Fallot

questions.correct_answer: B. T etr a logy of Fallot

questions.text: A 19-year- old male patient presents to the outpatient department due to recurrent chest infection, production of copious sputum, and hemoptysis for 2 weeks. He has had a history of cystic fibrosis , for which he takes medications regularly. Physical examinations reveal bilateral wheezing and inspiratory squeaks . The chest x-ray gives the following findings: What is the gold standard investigation to confirm the un derlying diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Specific findings of bronchial dilatation 
  • Signet ring sign (broncho-arterial ratio >1)
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Abnormal bronchial contour 
  • Visibility of peripheral airways 
Nonspecific findings 
  • Peribronchial cuffing (thickened hazy bronchial wall) 
  • Finger in glove opacities (mucus-filled bronchi) 
  • Multiple air-fluid levels (fluid-filled bronchi) 
Ancillary findings of small airway disease
  • Mosaic perfusion 
  • Air trapping 
  • Tree in bud opacities

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the pediatric OPD with the complaint of lethargy, poor growth speech and learning difficulties. On examination, she has macroglossia, coarse dry skin and growth retardation. An X-ray was done, which revealed stippled Epiphysis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45 - year - old woman, after total knee implant surgery, complain ed of calf pain and swelling in the leg for the last 2 days. S he later complain ed of breathlessness. An urgent chest X-ray was done, which show ed a Westermark sign. Which of the following describes the Westermark sign in Pulmonary Thromboembolism?

options.label: D
options.text: Prominence of Descending R igh t Pulmonary artery

questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ The Palla sign describes an enlarged right desending pulmonary artery and when present is suggestive of an occlusion of a lobar or segmental pulmonary artery or widespread occlusion of the small arteries.
  • ↳ The Palla sign describes an enlarged right desending pulmonary artery and when present is suggestive of an occlusion of a lobar or segmental pulmonary artery or widespread occlusion of the small arteries.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the physician with complaints of gradually increasing intervals between her menstrual cycle . She further gives a history that her last menstrual period was 4 months ago . The patient states that she is worried about her condition. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The clinician reassures her that these changes are normal for her age. Which of the following is true regarding the condition of the patient?

A 26-year-old patient known case of PCOS who is being treated for infertility and was prescribed clomiphene citrate 20 days ago for ovulation induction has now presented with sudden onset of abdominal pain and distension with ascites reported on abdominal ultrasound. What is the most probable cause of her symptoms?

A 40-year-old obese woman with type 2 diabetes and hypertension presented in an outpatient clinic with the complaint of heavy menstrual bleeding. After the biopsy, microscopic examination reveals endometriod type of endometrial carcinoma . The most probable gene defect expected in this condition is:
questions.explanation:
Type 1(Endometrioid type) Type 2(Serous, clear type)
  • Associated with PTEN gene mutations
  • Good prognosis
  • Estrogen-dependent, develop in the background of endometrial hyperplasia
  • Develops in obese women
  • Associated with HTN, diabetes
  • Associated with P-53 gene mutations
  • Poor prognosis
  • Not estrogen-dependent, develop in the background of atrophic endometrium
  • Develops in thin women
  • Not associated with HTN, diabetes

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to Gynecology OPD with complaints of abdominal distention and pain over the previous 3 months. Her physical examination reveals an abdominal mass without shifting dullness and bilateral adnexal masses. Her digital rectal examination reveals the presence of induration in the rectal pouch. Her breast examination and recent mammogram are normal. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.correct_answer: A. Serous cystadenocarcinomas of both ovaries

questions.text: A 22-year-old girl presents to the OPD with moderate acne. She gives a history of sudden gain in weight. On further questioning, she also has irregular menses. The doctor chooses to prescribe her a combination pill for the regularization of her cycles. Which of the following pill content would additionally help with her acne?

A 55-year-old woman presented to the gynaecological clinic with a complaint of pelvic pain and menorrhagia for the past 8 months. She is diagnosed with endometrial cancer. Her hysterectomy is done immediately, looking at her condition and to do staging. Her anaemia is first corrected by blood transfusions preoperatively, following which the surgery is done. The catheter is left in situ for 7 days post-operatively because of extensive bladder dissection during surgery. This patient presents with purulent discharge from her wound after 7 days of surgery. Which of the following is LEAST likely risk factor related to her presenting condition?

A 34-year-old woman presents with the first episode of heavy vaginal bleeding with the passage of clots over the past 2 days. Her past cycles have been delayed, with normal flow, and lasted 3-4 days. She had a USG two months back for irregular cycles, which showed a simple ovarian cyst of 3 cm. Which is the next most appropriate step in management?

A 30-year-old G2P1 presents to the outpatient department at the 37th week of gestation. She has no complaints, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated till now. History is significant for previous LSCS . She feels normal fetal activity, and her antenatal investigations are within normal limits. CTG is unremarkable. Pelvic examination shows a closed os and clinically inadequate pelvis . Which of the following is the best step in the delivery management of the patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Wait for spontaneous labor with a trial of labor in a tertiary care setup only

options.label: C
options.text: Elective LSCS at 39th week or emergency LSCS at the onset of labor

questions.correct_answer: C. Elective LSCS at 39th week or emergency LSCS at the onset of labor

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman, G3P2, at 16 weeks of gestation, comes to the clinic for a routine antenatal visit. She had cervical conisation for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 7 years ago. Her previous two pregnancies ended as preterm deliveries . Her physical examination is unremarkable. The length of the cervix is 2 cm on transvaginal ultrasound. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient to prevent preterm birth?

options.label: D
options.text: Serial measurement of cervical length via transvaginal ultrasound until 24 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A 26-yrs-old patient has had three consecutive spontaneous abortions early in her pregnancy. As part of an evaluation for this problem, the least useful tests would be Hysterosalpinogram Chromosomal analysis of the couple Testing for TORCH infections Endometrial biopsy in the luteal phase Postcoital test

A 23-year-old primigravida presents with mild abdominal pain for one week. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks. An ultrasound reveals a 2.5 cm gestational sac in the left fallopian tube. All of the following drugs may be used for medical management of this patient except?

A primigravida presents to the emergency department at 9 weeks of pregnancy with excessive nausea and vomiting. She has been avoiding spicy and oily food and has been taking oral antiemetics with only transient relief. The patient reveals that despite nausea and vomiting, she is eating well and is staying hydrated. Which of these is NOT a compelling reason for hospitalization in this patient?

A 20-year-old primigravida, at 33 weeks of gestation, is brought to the emergency department complaining of an absence of fetal movement for the last two days. She didn't receive any antenatal care or pregnancy check-up except a USG at 32 weeks, suggesting a growth retarded fetus corresponding to 30 weeks of fetal age. Her vitals are normal on examination, and the physician advises an antenatal doppler scan to assess fetal status. Which of the following umbilical artery Doppler findings is the most significant indication for termination of the pregnancy?

A group of researchers were conducting a study on the effects of infections in pregnancy on the developing fetus. They reviewed medical records of pregnant women from different maternity hospitals. An association was found between maternal infection and congenital fetal defects. It was observed that a newborn is born with cerebral cortical atrophy, bone and limb defects, cutaneous scarring and chorioretinitis when the mother develops an infection in the first trimester of pregnancy. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of these congenital anomalies in the newborn?

A 33-year-old pregnant woman presents to the antenatal clinic at 33 weeks of gestation complaining of itching all over her body. There is no history of fever or rashes. The physician rules out any underlying skin condition. Lab tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug therapy?

Caretakers bring a newborn delivered at home to assess for an abnormality suspected in his lower spine. The paediatrician examines it and finds that the baby's sacrum is hypoplastic. Which of the following antenatal history in the mother should be looked for?

A 26-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 12 weeks of gestation, presents to the obstetric outpatient department for her antenatal visit. Her ultrasound scan reveals twin pregnancies and a nuchal translucency of 2.2 and 2.8 mm in the fetuses. As her pregnancy progresses, she gets her quadruple marker test done at 17 weeks of gestation, which suggests deranged biochemical markers. Her history reveals no risk factor for chromosomal anomalies. Which of the following is the correct explanation of her deranged biomarker findings?

options.label: A
options.text: She is at a very high risk of having aneuploidy as the quadruple marker is positive, and, a normal nuchal translucency is less significant in twins

options.label: B
options.text: Nuchal translucency is not accurate here as it should have been done at 9-11 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: In twin gestation, nuchal translucency is more accurate than biochemical markers; hence, the risk of aneuploidy is less

options.label: D
options.text: Both tests are deranged and suggestive of aneuploidy risk

questions.correct_answer: C. In twin gestation, nuchal translucency is more accurate than biochemical markers; hence, the risk of aneuploidy is less

questions.text: In a 33 year old woman who conceived with IVF, an USG at 12 weeks shows a single developing fetus. The previous USG at 6 weeks showed a twin pregnancy. The patient has unremarkable medical history, takes only vitamins. Vital signs and physical examination are normal. What should be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Advice medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) as the second twin is at increased risk of aborting

options.label: B
options.text: Continue pregnancy like a normal singleton pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: Watch for coagulation defects in the mother

questions.correct_answer: B. Continue pregnancy like a normal singleton pregnancy

questions.text: A 29 year old woman is on HCG follow up after her previous pregnancy with complete mole was terminated by suction and evacuation. All of the following features are high risk factors for the development of choriocarcinoma except:

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of bilateral theca lutein cysts of ovary.

questions.text: A P1L1 woman with previous normal delivery, presents with irregular bleeding and uterine mass. The HCG is 8,120 mIU/mL. Biopsy reveals trophoblast tissue with absent chorionic villi with local invasion. The patient is now being evaluated for spread of disease and prognosis. Which of the following is TRUE about the patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Most common site of metastasis is vagina

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of Lung metastasis classifies as stage 4 GTN

options.label: C
options.text: This HCG value has a good prognosis

options.label: D
options.text: Prognosis is good as previous pregnancy is a full term delivery

questions.correct_answer: C. This HCG value has a good prognosis
questions.explanation:
PROGNOSTIC SCORING 0 1 2 4
1. Age <=39 >39    
2. Antecedent pregnancy mole abortion term pregnancy  
3. Interval (pregnancy and start of CT) <4 4-6 7-12 >12
4. Hcg <10,000 1000 - 10,000 10,000 - 1 lakh >1 lakh
5. Blood group   O or A B or AB  
6. Largest tumor size <3 3-5 >5  
7. Site of metastasis   spleen, kidney GIT Brain, liver
8. No. of metastasis   1-3 4-8 >8
9. Prior chemotherapy     1 drug >=2 drugs

questions.text: A 6-month-baby presented with recurrent seizures and developmental delay. On examination, there was alopecia and scaly skin rashes . Investigations revealed metabolic acidosis, elevated lactates and ketonuria . What could be the underlying enzyme deficiency?

A 27-year-old female presents to the Gynaecology Department complaining of lower abdominal pain associated with vaginal bleeding for the last two days. She is primigravida and has gestational amenorrhea of 30 weeks . Her CTG shows decelerations suggestive of fetal distress. A newborn weighing 1000 g is born. The child is suffering from respiratory distress within 1 hour of birth. Which of the following is the diagnostic possibility?

A newborn with a gestational age of 34 weeks and a birth weight of 1600 grams has been managed in a warmer for the last 18 hours. On examination, the neonate is shivering and has a heart rate of 122 beats per minute and a respiratory rate of 60 breaths per minute. The child has an axillary temperature of <36.5° and a warm abdomen but cold extremities. What is the quick diagnosis that should be made in this clinical setting?
questions.explanation:
Trunk Extremities Interpretation
Warm Warm Normal
Warm Cold Cold stress
Cold Cold Hypothermia

questions.text: A preterm neonate with low birth weight is kept in the neonatal ICU as the child's bilirubin levels are relatively high . He was given phototherapy and steroids for lung maturity as a treatment. While phototherapy was being given, his eyes were covered with a cotton pad, but a dark, greyish-brown skin discolouration was noticed after a few days. What could be the possible reason behind this colour change?

A preterm newborn was delivered after a C-section . On assessment, his APGAR score was 1 ; his birth weight was 1000 g . On Neonatal Resuscitation, HR < 100/min + no respirations → Positive pressure ventilation, no response with PPV → Endotracheal intubation , HR < 60/min → Chest compressions, no response to chest compressions → Epinephrine . What would be the ratio of chest compressions : positive pressure ventilation?

A 4-year-old child presents at the clinic with a complaint of a cough persisting for 1 month, a low-grade fever, night sweats, and failure to thrive . The medical history is significant. However, the family history is positive for a recent diagnosis of tuberculosis in the grandfather . The chest X-ray of the child given below suggests which of the following?
An 18-month-old child who has received one dose of DTP and OPV at 2 months of age. What will be your next immunisation plan?

options.label: A
options.text: Restart the immunisation schedule as per age

options.label: B
options.text: Measles, BCG, a booster dose of DPT and OPV

options.label: C
options.text: Measles, a booster dose of DPT and OPV

options.label: D
options.text: BCG, 2nd dose of DPT and OPV

questions.correct_answer: C. Measles, a booster dose of DPT and OPV
questions.explanation:
Age Vaccine
At birth BCG, bOPV-0, Hep B-0
6 weeks bOPV-1, Pentavalent-1, Rotavirus-1*, fIPV-1, PCV-1*
10 weeks bOPV-2, Pentavalent-2, Rotavirus-2*
14 weeks bOPV-3, Pentavalent-3, Rotavirus-3*, fIPV-2, PCV-2*
9 months MR-1*, JE-1*, PCV-B*, Vit-A
16-24 months DPT-B1, bOPV-B, JE-2*, MR-2*
5-6 years DPT-B2
11-13 yrs HPV-1*, HPV-2*

questions.text: A one-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to concerns about poor weight gain and difficulty feeding . On examination, the pediatrician notes that the infant is tachypneic and has a mild cyanotic hue . Auscultation reveals a widely split S2 and an ejection systolic murmur at the left sternal border. The infant's oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. A chest X-ray is given in the image. An echocardiogram is performed, which shows an anomaly, and the right atrium and ventricle are enlarged . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? What is the diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return (TAPVR)

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to a pediatrician with difficulty breathing for the past few hours. For the past few days, he has had low-grade fevers, runny nose, and barking cough . On examination, there is audible inspiratory stridor. Lungs are clear to auscultation. He does not appear to be in acute distress. Chest X-ray is performed as shown below: He is started on symptomatic treatment, and his symptoms improve in a few days. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35 years old male came to the E.N.T. outpatient department with complaints of fluctuating hearing loss and experienced a sudden onset of spinning sensations and imbalance associated with a ringing in her left ear. The patient also reports progressive left-sided hearing loss and is unable to follow conversations in noisy surroundings. On physical examination patient also complained of hearing the same sound in two different frequencies. There is horizontal nystagmus to the right. Which of the following test is confirmatory for this condition?

A 9-year-old child presents to the ENT department with complaints of recurrent bony fractures and reduced hearing for one year. The patient is vitally stable. On further investigation, tympanometry showed the following findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type Implications
Type A Normal tympanogram/sensorineural hearing loss where conductive mechanism is normal.
Type B Flat curve, no change in compliance with pressure changes. Seen in fluid in the middle ear.
Type C Maximum compliance in negative pressure. Seen in eustachian tube obstruction.
Type As Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure. Seen in otosclerosis or malleus fixation.
Type Ad High compliance at or near ambient pressure. Seen in ossicular discontinuity.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to the office with a complaint of nasal obstruction for the past two months. His mother also reports foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On nasal endoscopy, the obstruction caused by crust formation is noted. He denies any bad smell. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

A 50-year-old presents to the clinic with a growth involving the right nasal cavity invading bone of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, medial wall of orbit & ethmoid sinuses. No cervical lymph nodes are detected. The metastatic evaluation is negative. A biopsy is performed, and the report shows squamous cell carcinoma. What would be the further best treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ T 3 : Tumor invades any of the following: Bone of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, subcutaneous tissues, floor or medial wall of the Orbit, pterygoid fossa, and ethmoid sinuses.
  • ↳ No metastasis or nodal involvement is making it stage III (T3No Mo).
  • ↳ Treatment of choice for carcinoma maxillary sinus stage III (T 3 N 0 M 0 ): Combined Surgery & R.T.
  • ↳ Research has shown that surgical excision with clear margins is the standard of care and results in the lowest recurrence rate.
  • ↳ This is often done by an external approach, including lateral rhinotomy, partial rhinectomy, and total rhinectomy.
  • ↳ Patients who have insufficient margins are at significantly increased risk of local or regional recurrence of disease, even if radiation is given afterwards.
  • ↳ Total rhinectomy is often deferred with a preference for radiation therapy for multiple reasons. Patients may be concerned about the cosmetic appearance and emotional impact of such an extensive surgery.
  • ↳ Early cases with Stage I and II squamous cell carcinomas are treated with only surgery or radiation with similar results.
  • ↳ Chemoradiation- Used for large and inoperable tumors.
  • ↳ Stage Grouping of Cancer of Maxillary and Ethmoid Sinuses Stage 1 T 1 N 0 M 0 Stage II T 2 N 0 M 0 Stage III T 3 N 0 M 0 T 1 or T 2 or T 3 with N 1 M 0 Stage IV A T 4 N 0 M 0 T 4 N 1 M 0 Stage IV B Any T N 2 M 0 Any T N 3 M 0 Stage IV C Any T Any N M 1
  • ↳ Stage Grouping of Cancer of Maxillary and Ethmoid Sinuses
  • ↳ Stage Grouping of Cancer of Maxillary and Ethmoid Sinuses
  • ↳ Stage Grouping of Cancer of Maxillary and Ethmoid Sinuses

  • ↳ Stage 1
  • ↳ T 1 N 0 M 0
  • ↳ Stage II T 2 N 0 M 0
  • ↳ Stage II
  • ↳ T 2 N 0 M 0
  • ↳ Stage III T 3 N 0 M 0 T 1 or T 2 or T 3 with N 1 M 0
  • ↳ Stage III
  • ↳ T 3 N 0 M 0 T 1 or T 2 or T 3 with N 1 M 0
  • ↳ Stage IV A T 4 N 0 M 0 T 4 N 1 M 0
  • ↳ Stage IV A
  • ↳ T 4 N 0 M 0 T 4 N 1 M 0
  • ↳ Stage IV B Any T N 2 M 0 Any T N 3 M 0
  • ↳ Stage IV B
  • ↳ Any T N 2 M 0 Any T N 3 M 0
  • ↳ Stage IV C Any T Any N M 1
  • ↳ Stage IV C
  • ↳ Any T Any N M 1
  • ↳ Option A: Surgery only
  • ↳ Surgery and radiotherapy are used to treat maxillary sinus carcinoma stage III. Surgery alone can't give the results required.
  • ↳ Surgery and radiotherapy are used to treat maxillary sinus carcinoma stage III. Surgery alone can't give the results required.
  • ↳ Option B: Radiotherapy
  • ↳ Radiotherapy alone is not enough for treating maxillary carcinoma stage III. The best treatment is a combination of both surgery and radiotherapy.
  • ↳ Radiotherapy alone is not enough for treating maxillary carcinoma stage III.
  • ↳ The best treatment is a combination of both surgery and radiotherapy.
  • ↳ Option D: Chemoradiotherapy
  • ↳ Chemoradiotherapy has not been able to show promising results for treating maxillary carcinoma.
  • ↳ Chemoradiotherapy has not been able to show promising results for treating maxillary carcinoma.

Stage Grouping of Cancer of Maxillary and Ethmoid Sinuses
Stage 1 T1 N0 M0
Stage II T2 N0 M0
Stage III T3 N0 M0 T1 or T2 or T3 with N1 M0
Stage IV A T4 N0 M0 T4 N1 M0
Stage IV B Any T N2 M0 Any T N3 M0
Stage IV C Any T Any N M1

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presents to the clinic complaining of a throat lump for the last 4 weeks. There is no difficulty in swallowing or respiration. The feeling of a lump is more marked between meals . The patient is worried that the lump may be some cancer . Her pharyngeal examination is completely unremarkable and shows no pathology . Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of recurrent aspiration for the past month. He underwent lateral skull base surgery a few months back and had experience aspiration episodes ever since. There is no change in the voice of the patient. Which of the following nerve is most likely injured during surgery?

A 35-year-old woman presents to the physician's office with complaints of hoarseness of voice for the past month. She is a biology teacher and says that due to workload, she used to take extra classes to complete the syllabus on time. On laryngoscopic examination, the findings seen are as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

An 8-year-old boy presented to the ophthalmology clinic with a history of bilateral red sore eyes for 6 weeks. His family history is insignificant. His vitals are stable. On examination of his eyes, a characteristic finding is noted, which is shown in the given image. Which of the following diseases/syndrome would have this particular finding?
A 23 yr old male was recently diagnosed with herpetic keratitis. Which of the following is used in the treatment of such patients?

A 45-year-old female presents to the ophthalmology department with three days history of mild irritation, watering, and localized redness in the right eye, as shown below. Her past medical history reveals that she is a known case of hypertension and takes lisinopril 5mg daily. On history, it is confirmed that she is compliant with her medication. Her blood pressure at the visit is 125/85 mmHg. The resident ophthalmologist wants to differentiate between scleritis and episcleritis. He instills 10% phenylephrine, and there is quick blanching of the vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Nodular

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with progressive deterioration of vision. He also complained of missing things out of the corner of his eye. On examination, the pupillary reaction is sluggish, and IOP is normal. Fundoscopy shows a large and deep cup with p rogressive excavation or 'cupping' of the optic nerve head from retinal nerve fibre layer loss resulting in corresponding visual field deficits. Visual field reveals paracentral scotoma. What is the probable diagnosis?

A forty-six-year-old patient presents to your clinic with the complaint of visual difficulties in his right eye. He was recently diagnosed with a cataract in his right eye and was operated on for it with the placement of an intraocular lens. Eye examinations are performed. When the patient is asked to look from side to side, a pendulum motion resembling the action of a windshield wiper is noted. What is the cause of the patient’s condition?

A 40-year-old man presents to the eye clinic with complaints of photophobia, blurred vision, and floaters for the past 3 days. The patient also has a past medical history of an inflammatory condition for which he takes steroids on and off. The general physical examination was unremarkable except for a few round skin lesions on the shins . On fundal examination, snowball opacities and snow banking appearance are observed. What is the most relevant blood investigation in this clinical scenario?
questions.correct_answer: D. ACE level in the blood

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the physician with complaints of progressive loss of vision in both eyes over the past 8 months. The patient further gives a history that he has had blurry vision during this time and glare in the evenings. His blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg at the time of the check-up. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and raised serum cholesterol. A slit lamp shows cloudy opacities of the lenses bilaterally. His surgery was planned. A retrobulbar block was given in the retrobulbar space. Which of the following is a part of the space involved in this case?

options.label: B
options.text: All parts of Tenon’s capsule enclosing the globe

questions.correct_answer: B. All parts of Tenon’s capsule enclosing the globe

questions.text: A 70-year-old schoo l teacher presents to the ophthalmologist with sudden onset of blurring of vision from the last 6 hours. Her examination reveals that she had isolated superior rectus paresis . Magnetic resonance imaging reveals a small-sized infarct in the oculomotor nucleus on the contralateral side. Which of the following features can be present in this patient?

A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with a blistering rash on the face and scalp for the past three months. The rash appears as fragile blisters which break easily, leaving crusted erythematous ulcers on the skin. He also complains of pain and itching. The rash does not involve the oral cavity. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Skin examination shows shallow erosions on the scalp, face, and the right armpit with an erythematous base. Image shows the result of applying pressure in the perilesional area: Bulla spread sign is also positive. On direct immunofluorescence, desmoglein 1 antibody is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pemphigus vulgaris (most common) Pemphigus foliaceus
Clinical feature:

Early disease → desmoglein -3(Mucosa)

Late disease → desmoglein -3> desmoglein-1(Skin)

 Desmoglein -1 Only Skin involvement
Investigations
Histological: Row of tombstone appearance Positive Positive
DIF Positive Positive
Fish net like Pattern Positive Positive
IgG Ab Desmoglein 3 > 1 Desmoglein 1

questions.text: A 6-day-old male infant presents to the clinic accompanied by his mother with a complaint of purpuric skin lesions on the upper body since birth. During pregnancy, the mother had a flu-like illness with a maculopapular rash on her face and body. Physical examination of the neonate reveals a low birth weight, cataracts, and a grade II/VI continuous murmur most audible in the left infraclavicular region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Early Congenital Syphilis Late Congenital Syphilis
  • Extremely variable.
  • Most infants are asymptomatic at birth.
  • 2/3 manifest around 3-8 weeks.
  • By three months, most infants manifest.
  • Contagious.
  • Delayed consequences of localized inflammatory processes established at sites of treponemal infection during an early stage of the disease.
  • Seen beyond 2nd year of life.
  • Correspond to Tertiary stage of acquired syphilis.
  • Non-infectious.
  • BUENO'S TRIAD: Snuffles, Palmar & plantar bullae, Splenomegaly.
  • MARFAN'S DIAGNOSTIC PENTAD: Bueno's Triad, Pseudoparalysis, Cutaneous syphilis.

HUTCHINSON'S TRIAD- Pathognomonic sign

  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Eighth nerve deafness
  • Hutchinson's teeth: Upper central incisors- shorter, widely spaced, have a notch in biting edge- peg or screwdriver shape.

CUTANEOUS LESIONS

  • Vesiculobullous rash: Pemphigus syphilitics – earliest,
  • Rash: Large pink macules, papules, plaques,
  • Condyloma lata,
  • Nail changes: Paronychia, claw nail, shedding of nails,
  • Hair changes: Alopecia, brittle sparse hair.

MUCOSAL LESIONS

  • Rhinitis (snuffles): Earliest watery nasal discharge thicker, purulent and bloody - Breathing and suckling difficulties
  • Pharyngitis & obstruction of the larynx occurs with characteristic hoarse cry (syphilitic aphonia) and cough.

SKELETAL INVOLVEMENT

  • Osteochondritis of long bones: earliest (upper end of tibia, the distal end of radius, and ulna).
  • Pseudo-paralysis of Parrot: (symptomatic- pain and tenderness)
  • Syphilitic Dactylitis: Painless, fusiform swelling of the digits; osteochondritis of phalanges.

SYPHILITIC STIGMATA

  • Frontal bossing.
  • Hot cross bun deformity- Parietal bone inv.
  • Olympian or beetled brow.
  • A high cranium or "tower skull."
  • Saddle-nose deformity.
  • Short maxilla, high palatal arch, prominent mandible- bulldog jaw.
  • Scaphoid shape scapula.
  • Circumoral radiating furrows (rhagades).
  • Hoarseness of voice.
  • Sabre tibia: Anterior bending of tibia
  • Hutchinson's teeth

Congenital Toxoplasmosis Congenital Rubella Congenital Cytomegalovirus
  • Classic triad
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Diffuse intracranial calcifications (ring-enhancing lesions)
    • Petechiae and purpura (blueberry muffin rash)
  • IUGR
  • Sensorineural Deafness
  • Cataracts
  • Heart defects (e.g., PDA, pulmonary artery stenosis)
  • CNS abnormalities
  • Petechiae and purpura (blueberry muffin rash)
  • Jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly
  • IUGR
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Sensorineural Deafness
  • Periventricular calcifications
  • Petechiae and purpura (blueberry muffin rash)
  • Microcephaly
  • Seizures
